posts.cooked: The Toshiba I am using is having a real struggle loading MS Visual Studio Code and the various extensions. The windows 8.1 is losing support by build season anyway. I think it’s time. Any suggestions? Thx

What computer you want to computer mainly depends on your budget and you needs. I mean if you’re only going to be using VS Code and browsing the web, you won’t really need that powerful of a computer. “Best” (arguably) windows laptop is considered to be the XPS 13 and if you want a MacBook, an entry level M1 MacBook Air will definitely be fast enough for basically anything.

posts.name: MikLast
posts.cooked:
Budget is also important. We can recommend the most top of the line computers, but if you only have $200 to spend, everyones time is instead wasted.

If you’re more technically inclined in the realm of PC building, the Framework is something to look into (just ignore the “chromebook” one, they have Windows versions). I currently own the 11th gen DIY version, and for the most part I love it (very much prefer to have a numpad, but compromises had to be made). If you play it right, you can find the RAM/SSD for cheaper and save a few bucks, which is what I did.

If your budget is tight, used thinkpads. Someone will likely come by with a more exact suggestion if there are serious budget constraints.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Anything with a Ryzen CPU, 16+gb ram, 500+gb UPGRADEABLE SSD (m.2) storage, a 1080p screen, and plenty of ports. As long as it’s not a Dell, and doesn’t come with Windows 11. Dell sells you a warranty with a side of a computer Windows 11 is a joke

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked: Been meaning to ask for help, we are looking for a new driver’s station laptop that has plenty of ports and is reliable. Ideally it would be under $1k. Any recommendations?

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked: I’m a huge fan of tough books for robotics, as they have proven to be very durable in many cases. I especially love the ones with handles that carry like brief cases because I can confidently carry it around with one hand and not be afraid of breaking it.

posts.name: Josh Fan
posts.cooked: One thing to note is that no matter the cost or processing power, there are a few necessary components to any laptop. Remember to get a laptop with an ethernet port as lots of new laptops now don’t have one. Also, get lots of USB ports for controllers and such. Maybe an SD card reader if you deal with Rasp Pis.

posts.name: Jacob Frye
posts.cooked: I just got a 12th gen framework, and I love it. Completely customizable, can replace any components that wear out/are obsolete, I am hoping I can keep the same chassis for a long time to come

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
gellnick:

Used Thinkpad.

gellnick:

Dell sells you a warranty with a side of a computer

I believed this two years ago, but then both of my Lenovo Thinkpad products were BIOS error BSOD-prone nightmares and replacing them with a “business class” ( ) Dell XPS15 9500 was a rock solid move. YMMV.

(Recently my Lenovo got an update and finally can be unplugged from the charger without bluescreening (BSOD, bluescreen of death)…)

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: I have an 11th gen framework and I was originally a bit worried about it since it’s an iGPU but it handles anything I can throw at it for FRC including inventor and rendering.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked:
+1 for ThinkPads The workstation line are great and the TrackPoint mouse is awesome. Waaaay better for CAD than a trackpad.

On a side note other brands have similar nub mice but none have, in my experience, been as good as ThinkPad’s Trackpoint.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
anon37142155:

“Best” (arguably) windows laptop is considered to be the XPS 13

My college son’s XPS 13 that just had its 4th (or was it 5th?) motherboard failure would like a word.

Of course my Dell Precision laptop from a similar era has been rock solid, and 6328 has had over the years a rotating cast of donated corporate-class mostly-Dell laptops that have by and large worked quite well.  YMMV…
You could argue that after 4 or 5 failures its a problem overall with XPS 13 or its something in the way your son uses the laptop.

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: l am curious about which series of thinkpad can do FRC work smoothly, including doing CAD on solidworks and coding? (To be more specific, which configuration must a laptop have if l want to use it to do the CAD work and coding work smoothly if l have enough budget?) l think my Thinkpad X390 with a 8GB onboard RAM can only do the coding work smoothy . If l try to see a cad file via solidworks or Autodesk Inventor, it will take up 80%-90% of my RAM and everything will be slow since then.

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked: It’s not him.  He treats his electronics with more care than almost anyone I know.  This particular XPS13 variant from ~4 years ago is just problematic (and we’ve now given up on it).

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
I have extensive experience with both.

Dell business class machines are pretty hardy.   Not as hardy as Thinkpads, but pretty good.

After all, someone who makes as many as they make end up learning something about manufacturing and warranty costs.

Lenovo’s refurb outlet is pretty good in my experience. https://www.lenovo.com/us/outletus/en/p/laptops/thinkpad/thinkpadp/thinkpad-p17/20snx017us

The last time around, we purchased thinkpads that had internal permanent batteries AND the click-in swap-able batteries.  I.e., a true 10 hours of battery life.  Those have been lifesavers and we’ve loved them.

If budget is an over-riding factor, Dell will be a more appealing option. https://outlet.us.dell.com/ARBOnlineSales/Online/SecondaryInventorySearch.aspx?c=us&cs=22&l=en&s=dfh&sign=PXhcOSHtr1T4IOw%2FPR7UdQPcQRJu87smM1WEDZsHn7OzBdwBeQ9g8v4oSy%2FYlGOlqISIYkjkhgOs7knyrAQLJS45Kh1fLquz6k7NALO5CZ0oGAMH6adlE9hEtmI0RCsq0lzd9dpG%2F0jpCaX0iFwm6yCyNbgxBG1vlsSMzIrhAXvoh5Ex2Mx%2FpD1ikawxuJ4A%2FF3nbeZ5kNU%3D

I have not confirmed the Dell above has a full-size ethernet port, as opposed to the stupid ‘collapse-able’ deals I’ve seen on some that break in no time at all.

link_counts.title: ThinkPad P17 Gen 1 | Lenovo US Outlet

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked:
My daily driver laptop is an old ThinkPad P50 with a Intel Core i7-6700HQ, 32 gb of ram and an SSD.

Looks like you can get a P50 for next to nothing these days: https://smile.amazon.com/Lenovo-ThinkPad-20EN0013US-15-6-Laptop/dp/B0186JD544

It is defiantly a bit sluggish these days when multitasking but it can handle large SolidWorks assemblies no problem.
